title: AB322 Land-2-Sea Tutorial
text:
UNIS course AB-322 is titled “Fluxes of Nutrients, Energy and Contaminants from Sea to Land”, a title that largely ignores the arguably larger fluxes moving in the opposite direction: from land to sea.
Here, we have compiled an R tutorial focused on 5 Arctic rivers and their role in transporting nutrients, carbon and contaminants from thawing catchments to coastal waters in Isfjorden, Svalbard.


This tutorial requires you to have R and Rstudio installed on your computer. Go to the R website and follow the links for downloading.
R for Windows: https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/base/.
R for Macs: https://cran.r-project.org/bin/macosx/.
R-studio: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/
Once you have Rstudio installed, click on File/New File/Rscript. We will use this new Rscript file for loading, cleaning and plotting catchment and river water chemistry data throughout this tutorial.



In addition, you will need to install several R packages. You can do this by copying and running the following lines of code in your new Rscript.
install.packages("tidyverse") 
install.packages("vegan")






This book was created using Quarto.

title: Preface
text:
Downstream impacts of terrestrial inputs on coastal waters can be dramatic, with impacts on light climate, nutrient availability and contamination in fjord surface waters (McGovern et al., 2020). However, these impacts are shaped by the characteristics of the inflowing freshwater, with concentrations of suspended sediments, carbon, nutrients, and contaminants varying among river catchments with differing morphology, geology, vegetation cover, and glacial coverage (refs). In the Arctic, river catchments are spatially heterogeneous, seasonally variable, and facing rapid changes with climate warming.
Climate change impacts on cross-ecosystem transport of solutes from Arctic catchments to coastal waters is driven both by changes in discharge, and in water chemistry. Discharge is increasing for many Arctic rivers due to increases in precipitation, glacial melt and permafrost thaw. In addition, thawing catchments and increased vegetative biomass ‘Arctic Greening’, are leading to changes in river water chemistry, with implications for receiving coastal waters.
In this tutorial, we will explore two cross-boundary fluxes of carbon, nutrients and contaminants: (1) from catchment soils to rivers, and (2) from rivers to sea.

title: Preface
text:
Ackowledgements
Water chemistry data used in this tutorial include published data (McGovern et al., 2020) and unpublished data collected by NIVA under the NFR project ’TerrACE’and Framcenter project “FreshFate”; PI, Amanda Poste. In addition, some of the data used here are generated for teaching purposes.

title: Introduction
text: The rivers investigated in this tutorial include Adventelva, Sassenelva, DeGeerelva, Gipsdalselva and Ebbaelva. These rivers drain catchments with varying morphology and vegetation cover and all flow into the Isfjorden system on the west coast of Svalbard.

title: 2  Catchment Characteristics
text:
Note



Here, we define a catchment (catchment basin, watershed, nedbørfelt) as the area from which rainfall flows into a river, lake, or reservoir.

title: 1  River water chemistry
text: River water chemistry data were collected in May, June, August in 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021

title: 1  River water chemistry
text:
1.1 Solute Concentrations

# Load libraries
library(tidyverse)

# Load datafiles
Water_Chem <- read_csv("Datafiles/AB322_Water_Chemistry.csv")

# Arrange Month factor chronologically
Water_Chem$Month <- factor(Water_Chem$Month,levels = c("May", "June", "August"))


1.1.1 Carbon

# TOC, DOC, POC

P1 <- Water_Chem %>% 
  select(River, Month, DOC, TOC, POC) %>% 
  pivot_longer(cols= -c(River, Month), names_to = "Carbon", values_to= 'Concentration') %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Month, y = Concentration, color = Month)) + 
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("cornflowerblue","tan","lightsalmon4")) +
  facet_grid(Carbon~River, scales= "free") +
  ylab("Organic Carbon (umol/L)") + 
  xlab("River") +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, vjust = 1, hjust=1), text = element_text(size=14))

P1










Tip



Shortcut for the pipe (%>%): shift-command-m (mac); shift-control-m (windows)

  xlab("River") +

# Hg per gram Carbon

P4 <- Water_Chem %>% 
  select(River, Month, TotHg_g_DOC, TotHg_g_POC) %>% 
  pivot_longer(cols= -c(River, Month), names_to = "Mercury", values_to= 'Concentration') %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Month, y = Concentration, color = Month)) + 
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("cornflowerblue","tan","lightsalmon4")) +
  facet_grid(Mercury ~ River, scales = "free") +
  ylab("Concentration (mg/gC)") + 
  xlab("River") +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, vjust = 1, hjust=1), text = element_text(size=14))

P4







Note



Fluxes, rather than concentration data are more relevant for evaluating implications on coastal ecosystems and the Arctic ocean. Fluxes are calculated using concentrations and discharge.

text:

Glacier coverage

Note



In Arctic regions, most river runoff is constrained to the summer melt season due to seasonal variations in sunlight and temperature. Despite their importance, for simplification, we do not account for seasonal variability in river discharge and water chemistry in this example.

text: Now, we will combine data on catchment characteristics and river water chemistry to investigate differences among the 5 study catchments.

title: 3  Catchment Comparison
text:
3.2 Relationships to river water chemistry

3.2.1 PCA

# PCA of water chemistry 
library(vegan)

Loading required package: permute


Loading required package: lattice


This is vegan 2.6-2

library(ggrepel)

Water_Chem <- Water_Chem %>% drop_na()

Envar <- Water_Chem %>% 
  select(c(DOC, POC, NO2_NO3, PO4, SiO2, SPM, TotHg_Dissolved, TotHg_Particulate)) %>% 
  mutate_at(vars(c(DOC, POC, NO2_NO3, PO4, SiO2, SPM, TotHg_Dissolved, TotHg_Particulate)),~scale(.))

# PCA in Vegan
Water_Chem_PCA <- rda(Envar)
Water_Chem_PCA

Call: rda(X = Envar)

              Inertia Rank
Total               8     
Unconstrained       8    8
Inertia is variance 

Eigenvalues for unconstrained axes:
  PC1   PC2   PC3   PC4   PC5   PC6   PC7   PC8 
3.378 2.348 1.129 0.563 0.369 0.110 0.074 0.029 

# Plot
PCAscores <- scores(Water_Chem_PCA, display = "sites") %>% as.data.frame() 
PCAvect <- scores(Water_Chem_PCA, display = "species") %>% as.data.frame() %>% rownames_to_column("species")


#Plot
P4 <- ggplot() +
  geom_point(data = PCAscores, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2, color = Water_Chem$Month), 
             size= 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("#8B9DAF","tan","lightsalmon4")) + 
  theme_classic() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = c(0), color = "grey70", linetype = 2) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = c(0), color = "grey70", linetype = 2)  +
  labs(x = "PC1 ( %)", y = "PC2 ( %)") +  
  geom_segment(data = PCAvect, aes(x = 0, xend = PC1, y = 0, yend = PC2), 
               arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.1, "cm")), col = "black") +
  geom_text_repel(data = PCAvect, aes(x = PC1, y= PC2, label = species), parse = T, col="black", size = 3, segment.size = 0.15) +
  theme(text = element_text(size=),legend.text = element_text(size=rel(0.6)),legend.title = element_blank(), 
        panel.background = element_rect(colour = "black", size=1)) + ylim(-1.2,1.2) + xlim(-1.5,1.5)
P4
